subject: RE: [junit] How to automate the testcases!
msgSnippet: Unless I m wrong, JTest doesn t automatically generate anything that will test the logic of the classes under test. It automatically tests for coding standard
messageBody:
Unless I'm wrong, JTest doesn't automatically generate anything that will
test the logic of the classes under test. It automatically tests for coding
standard violations and potentially unhandled exceptions. So to test if your
classes actually work properly (provide services correctly) you'll have to
write tests.

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Mike Silverstein
SilverMark, Inc.
The object testing company
http://www.javatesting.com

> -----Original Message-----
> From: james.dobson@... [mailto:james.dobson@...]
> Sent: Monday, August 05, 2002 10:15 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] How to automate the testcases!
>
>
> Doesn't Parasofts Jtest do that? That's what there adverts say. But of
> course it isn't free.
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: k_b_konuri [mailto:k_b_konuri@...]
> Sent: 03 August 2002 09:16
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] How to automate the testcases!
>
>
> Hi,
> I want to test a library containing more than 1000 classes and
> lots of methods. so, it is extreemely difficult for me to write
> a Testcase(just like having VectorTest class for java.util.Vector in
> the examples given in JUint)for each and every class of my library
> and a correspoding test method(just like having testCapacity() method
> corresponding to Capacity() method in Java.util.Vector )with assert
> methods.
> Is there a way to automate this process, i mean given a class can a
> tool generate a corresponding Testclass having all testXXX(),setUp()
> and tearDown() methods.
> please let me know if this kind of feature is available with Junit or
> any Extended tools of JUnit.
> Thanks in Advance.
>
> Regards,
> Kishore.
>
